items.content_html:
Summary

Our current overview dashboard is aggregating and displaying data at the organization level, encompassing all repositories within the organization. To provide a more comprehensive view for larger enterprises, we aim to build an enterprise-level dashboard to aggregate and present data across all organizations within an enterprise. This enterprise-level dashboard will offer a macro view of application security metrics, aiding in broader strategic decisions and analyses.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users require the ability to analyze data across their enterprise. This feature will give application security users the ability to view aggregated data from all organizations within my enterprise in a single, unified dashboard so that they can easily compare and analyze metrics at an enterprise scale to make informed, overarching decisions regarding security and development practices.

How will it work?

Security managers and organization owners will be able to access an overview of code security metrics through the enterprise account page. This dashboard will offer a consolidated view of security metrics across organizations that are currently only available at the organization level.

In cases where users have access to multiple organizations, they will have the flexibility of filtering by organization.
items.title: Enterprise-level overview dashboard [Public Beta]

items.content_html:
Summary

While organization owners can create custom organization roles to control their users' access to the organization, we've found that there are common patterns that most organizations need. These roles will be built in to every GitHub organization, and available to all organizations, both enterprise and free, to provide a "batteries included" least-privilege setup.

We'll be adding new roles over time as features within GitHub add granular management. At launch, though, we'll have a set of five organization-wide base roles, which grant read, triage, write, maintain, or admin privileges against every repository in the organization. These can be assigned to organization members as well as organization teams.
items.title: Pre-defined organization roles

items.content_html:
Summary

With this feature, you can now group alerts by close reasons on the alert trends report and apply filters on the overview page based on close reason. This improvement encompasses alerts from all GitHub security tools—Dependabot, CodeQL, secret scanning—as well as third-party alerts.

Intended Outcome

Security managers often grapple with the high volume of closed alerts, making it difficult to extract meaningful insights. Key questions like, "How many alerts were dismissed as false positives?" or "How many were actually remediated?" can now be answered effortlessly. This feature aims to empower security managers to monitor, track, and audit resolved alerts with precision, ultimately enhancing your organization's ability to address and reduce vulnerabilities.

How will it work?

The updated security overview dashboard will introduce a new "Close Reason" grouping option within the alert trends graph. Additionally, you can apply filters using close reasons on both the dashboard and individual alert pages. For instance, you can display alerts marked as "risk accepted" using the filter close-reason:risk-accepted, allowing for a more granular and focused analysis of security alerts.

New close reason alert trends grouping:
items.title: Close reasons trends grouping and filters for the overview dashboard

items.content_html:
Summary

Elevate your enterprise's security with this new organization-level report, designed to proactively monitor and track preventative remediation activities and autofix metrics, ensuring vulnerabilities are addressed swiftly and efficiently. Additionally, this report is also designed to highlight the substantial value and return on investment that GitHub Advanced Security prevention tactics brings to your security operations.

Intended Outcome

Many security managers struggle to quantify the preventative impact of GitHub Advanced Security, understand the value that autofix delivers and communicate its benefits effectively. Wit this report, you'll have the data-driven metrics at your fingertips to effectively drive prevention strategies, demonstrate impact, and, ultimately, significantly mitigate enterprise risks.

How will it work?

Introducing a new, comprehensive report that aggregates CodeQL pull request alerts and breaks them down by repository, providing deep insights into your security landscape. This report will feature key metrics, including the most prevalent rules triggering pull request alerts, and detailed breakdowns of alert statuses—unresolved, merged, dismissed, and specifically, those fixed with or without autofix. Additionally, it will track and display trends in pull request alert volumes, offering a historical view that can be filtered extensively to suit your analytical needs.

Prototype report
items.title: Organization-level CodeQL pull request alerts report

items.content_html:
Summary

Enhance your understanding of your security landscape with our newly redesigned enterprise-level overview dashboard. This intuitive interface categorizes your security insights into three distinct, streamlined domains: detection, remediation, and prevention. Experience enhanced visibility with top-line metrics from GitHub Advanced Security’s preventative features such as secret scanning’s push protection and CodeQL’s alerts in pull requests. This refined design ensures that you can quickly and easily understand your security metrics, enabling more effective decision-making at a glance.

Intended Outcome

Security managers often struggle to effectively quantify and communicate the critical metrics from the key security activities. This redesigned dashboard makes it straightforward to navigate and understand the current status of your security operations. With immediate access to tangible metrics and insights, this feature empowers you to proactively manage prevention and remediation efforts, demonstrate their impact, and ultimately reduce your enterprise's risk exposure significantly.

How will it work?

The updated security overview dashboard introduces a dedicated prevention section, displaying essential metrics. You'll find vital indicators such as the number of vulnerabilities detected in pull requests, the tally of alerts resolved through autofix, and the count of secrets proactively blocked. Further, the existing dashboard components for detection and remediation have been refined to seamlessly integrate with this new structure. This comprehensive and actionable view enables your team to continually optimize and fortify your security protocols.
items.title: Enterprise-level overview dashbard organized by key domain

items.content_html:
Summary

In our commitment to enhancing the application security experience for our customers, we will soon be releasing an enterprise security manager role, designed to provide security oversight across your enterprise. This role is designed to empower a designated team with comprehensive security management capabilities across all organizations within your enterprise. Members assigned to this role will have the authority to manage enterprise-wide security settings and code security policies, access security-related enterprise APIs, and oversee all data within the enterprise-level security overview pages. Additionally, they will possess all the permissions currently held by organization-level security managers.

Intended Outcome

Our enterprise customers have expressed a more streamlined way to empower their security-focused teams without the added complexity of adding a security manager team to each organization. Moreover, these teams often require access to enterprise-level policies and security settings, which traditionally have been reserved for the enterprise owner or granted only partially. This new role addresses these needs by providing:

  • Simplified, centralized access management across all organizations with just a few clicks.
  • Expanded permissions that encompass both organization-level and enterprise-level oversight and control.

How will it work?

The enterprise security manager role is designed to be assigned collectively to an enterprise team and the process will involve only two steps:

  1. Create an enterprise team: Your enterprise owner will begin by forming an enterprise team, similar how you create a team at the organization level today.
  2. Grant organization membership and roles: Your enterprise owner will then grant organization membership and assign the security manager role to the enterprise team all in a few simple clicks.

Once the team is configured, team members will be able to:

  • Manage security settings and code security policies at the enterprise level.
  • Access enterprise-level security-related APIs.
  • View security data for all organizations in the enterprise-level security overview.
  • Retain the capabilities typically granted to organization security managers, including the ability to view and dismiss alerts and configure security settings at the organization and repository levels.
items.title: Enterprise security manager (beta)

items.content_html:
Summary

The GitHub-hosted runner portfolio is expanding to include Arm-based hosted runners. These runners will be fully managed by GitHub with a base image containing a foundational set of tools. Powered by the Ampere Altra Arm–based processor, these runners offer a power efficient compute layer which can increase price to performance ratios, allowing customers to optimize compute costs.

Intended Outcome

Customers are refactoring their applications to take advantage of the price performance benefits of ARM architecture. Developers can now run their workloads on Arm-based hardware hosted by GitHub to build and deploy their release assets anywhere Arm’s architecture is used. These new runners provide power, performance & sustainability improvements for all your Actions jobs.

How will it work?

These runners will be available for all GitHub Actions users. Users in private namespaces or working on open source will be able to target these runners with a new label in the runs-on key in their Actions workflow file.
items.title: GitHub Actions: Arm based hosted runners for OSS

items.content_html:
Summary

Secret scanning's push protection will support gists, preventing developers from accidentally leaking tokens in secret and public gists.

Intended Outcome

Gists remain an easy way for developers to save and share snippets of code. They can be a source of secret leaks. With push protection on gists, developers will be warned when they are about to leak a secret in a gist.

How will it work?

When a developer creates or updates a secret or public gist, secret scanning will check to see if the content includes a secret. If it does, the developer will we blocked and have the option to either remove the secret or bypass the block. Developers will not need to select a reason for bypassing. No secret scanning alerts will be created for secrets found in gists.
items.title: Secret scanning push protection for gists

items.content_html:
Summary

Code scanning will propose AI-generated fixes for CodeQL alerts in pull requests. These fixes help developers resolve alerts faster and prevent introducing new vulnerabilities into codebases.

This functionality will be available for all GHAS customers on GitHub.com.

Intended Outcome

Users can fix security vulnerabilities faster with the help of code scanning AI-generated remediation suggestions, which offer a convenient one-click fix option.

The UI will show statistics of generated fixes and suggestions that result in fixing alerts, as well as reasons for not displaying the autofix for the alert. Additionally, the UX will allow users to jump into an editing environment in order for developers to make any adjustments to the proposed fix.

How will it work?

Following the CodeQL analysis, an LLM (GPT 4) will propose a fix for any new alerts where possible. These AI-generated remediation suggestions are then posted as as a code scanning autofix on the PR's 'Conversation' and 'Files Changed' tabs.
items.title: Code scanning: AI-powered autofixes for CodeQL alerts in PRs

items.content_html:
Summary

Actions Usage Metrics is an observability tool for DevEx and DevOps teams interested in understanding how Actions workflows are being used by their organization. Time is the most important metric for DevOps and DevEx teams. The question they want answered is, “where are all my minutes going?” Actions Usage Metrics addresses this question and others by focusing on minutes used per workflow, job, repository, runtime OS, and runner type regardless if you're using hosted or self-hosted runners. This data helps organizations locate areas of improvement in their software delivery lifecycle, saving time and money.

Intended Outcome

Organizations get high quality, relevant and actionable data about Actions usage including workflow and job execution details for hosted and self hosted runners.

How will it work?

Customers can filter data by any combination of workflows, jobs, repositories, runtime OS, and runner type to view total minutes, number of jobs, workflow executions, and more. All usage metrics, filtered or not, can be downloaded as a .csv file to use with your tool of choice. By default, organization owners can access Actions Usage Metrics. However, access permissions can be granted to other members or teams using Actions fine-grained permissions. This ensures the right level of access to Actions Usage Metrics data, enabling informed decisions and improvements.
items.title: Actions Usage Metrics

items.content_html:
Summary

Currently, projects supports 1,200 active items and 10,000 archived items, but we've heard from many larger teams that these limits are too low for the work they need to track for long-running backlogs. We are increasing the limit to 50k active items per project, and we can increase further on a case-by-case basis.

Intended Outcome

For long running projects or all-encompassing backlogs for companies, the current limit for project items is too constricting. In order to better serve our large team and enterprise customers, we need to increase this limit so that their projects can grow as they do.

How will it work?

Projects will work as they do now, just with a higher upper limit on active items.
items.title: Projects: Unlimited items

items.content_html:
Summary

Secret scanning is expanding detection coverage beyond commit content. GitHub now detects secrets found in pull request and GitHub discussions (e.g. bodies, comments, edits).

As GitHub expands support, GitHub will be performing backfills to detect historically existing secrets across pull requests and discussions.

This release follows support of scanning for GitHub issues, and will be similarly followed by support for secret scanning across GitHub wiki content.

Intended Outcome

Secrets can be exposed anywhere -- not just across code content. GitHub helps keep you safe by automatically scanning additional surfaces across GitHub, without the need for any additional setup.

How will it work?

For repositories where secret scanning is enabled, you'll automatically begin to receive secret scanning alerts for any exposed secrets in pull requests or discussions. GitHub will also continue to scan public repositories for publicly leaked secrets, and will now notify partners in secret scanning's partnership program if secrets are detected in public pull requests or discussions.
items.title: Secret scanning detects secrets in GitHub discussions and pull request content

items.content_html:

items.title: Secret scanning detects secrets in GitHub wikis

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub apps will be able to call APIs on the enterprise object, by being installed on an enterprise and granted new, fine-grained permissions that control access to the Enterprise. This allows administrators to deprecate the use of PATs (classic) and OAuth apps to manage their enterprises.

Intended Outcome

GitHub apps need to be able to operate at the Enterprise layer in order to best automate enterprise operations like managing settings, provisioning users, and reading the audit log. This update helps remove one of the last reasons developers and administrators are forced to use OAuth apps instead of the more secure and manageable GitHub app platform.

How will it work?

App developers will be able to specify Enterprises as a resource target, similar to how organizations and users are selected today. New fine-grained permissions (such as enterprise_audit_log:read) will be created, which administrators can then grant to apps installed on their enterprise.

The initial permission that this will ship with is the ability to manage GitHub Apps installed on organizations in the enterprise. This will allow administrators to automate the installation, uninstallation, and blocking of apps within their enterprise. Note, though, that this is an enterprise-level access still and "Enterprise apps" don't otherwise get access to organizations in the enterprise.
items.title: Enterprise Apps and installation automation (Public Beta)

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub Action runners will now include the option to choose GPU runners to enable Machine learning Ops workloads to be run on GitHub actions. These new GPU runners come pre-loaded with the drivers and tools developers/data scientists need to run their models more efficiently as part of their CI/CD process, empowering teams to do complete application testing, including the ML components, in Actions.

Intended Outcome

Enable ML Ops workloads to fully embrace GitHub Actions without the overhead of managing their own infrastructure or paying a 3rd party provider to manage infrastructure for them.

How will it work?

Users will be able to enable GPU machines as part of their runner groups. From here their team will be able to pick up and use these runners simply by changing their runs-on: key within their workflow YAML. These are fully managed by GitHub and have all the drivers required for the users to just 'pick up and go' with their ML workloads
items.title: Actions: GPU enabled GitHub-hosted runners generally available

Summary

These new runners provide power, performance & sustainability improvements for all your Actions jobs.

How will it work?

To get started using Arm-based GitHub-hosted runners, create a runner in a runner group choosing Arm as the hardware. Then update the runs-on: key in your Actions workflow YAML to have those jobs target the new runner. These runners are available for GitHub Team & Enterprise plans only.
items.title: Actions: Arm based hosted runners generally available

items.content_html:
Summary

Actions Hosted runners will now include the option to build your own virtual machine image to power your workflows that are run on GitHub Actions. This allows developers to gain control over their supply chain and reduce the average duration of their workflows by customizing the software, tools, and files on Actions Hosted runners before a workflow starts.

Intended Outcome

33% of Actions people run are to set up tools/dependencies on their machine before they even start to download images/packages that their application is dependent on. This takes time on every run of that workflow. With custom images developers can now customize those pre-installed tools, saving time by creating a "pre-warmed" machine.

How will it work?

GitHub's image customization allows developers to use their existing workflow YAML to produce images which can be used as the base for their different developer environments. Developers can use the new syntax to take the state of their current environment and save that to an image to be used in future workflows.
items.title: Actions: Custom VM Images for GitHub-hosted runners generally available

items.content_html:
Summary

Actions will add the ability to run your workflow jobs on the latest Ubuntu version from Canonical.

Intended Outcome

Developers will be able to build and test their code on the latest version of Ubuntu.

How will it work?

Update your workflows to include runs-on: ubuntu-24.04

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-24.04

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Run a one-line script
        run: echo Hello from Octo Organization
items.title: Actions: Ubuntu 24 on GitHub-hosted runners (Beta)
